_header: Is [I shall?] tell you my mind Annis Taylor dame
_description: A plea to Annis Taylor for another drink — a Welsh-English ‘englyn’

BLHar3725.Transcription: …ffrend an we ar ffer In detffor your ffyn good wyn god wotshort is the Ioynt of your peynt potI drank wonis I wold drynk yet
BLHar3725.Note: Lines 5-8 only, addd to blank leaf by a later hand.
BLHar3725.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.  
             Secular Lyrics of the XIV and XV Centuries.
         2nd ed. Oxford: Clarendon, 1955: 229, 5.

BLAdd14997.First Lines:
Is tell yow my mynd anes tayliur dameI deme we lak
                    plesure…
BLAdd14997.Last Lines:
…A short gynt hase a pynt potteI dranke onys I wolde drinke
                    yette
BLAdd14997.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope,
                        ed.  
             Secular Lyrics of the XIV and XV Centuries.
         2nd ed. Oxford: Clarendon, 1955: 229, 5.
Sisam,  Celia,  and  Kenneth Sisam, eds.  
             The Oxford Book of Medieval English Verse.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1970: 512.
Luria,  Maxwell Sidney,  and  Richard L. Hoffman, eds.  
             Middle English Lyrics.
         New York: Norton, 1974: 143.
